source.description: Follow the steps detailed in the "Before Start" section prior to moving forward in this protocol.
Invert vacutainer 5x to mix blood.

source.body: Do not shake.

source.description: For transferring blood to the different tubes, proceed ONLY one patient sample set at a time and avoid opening and closing vacutainers.

Gently open one vacutainer and move whole blood to a separate 15mL conical tube for neutrophil isolation based on the amount of blood received.
  • 4-8ml blood - take 5000ul for neutrophil isolation
  • 2-3ml blood - take 250ul for neutrophil isolation
  • don't take blood for neutrophil isolation if there is < 2ml of blood

source.body: Do not put on ice.
This step could be skipped if neutrophil isolation is not needed.

source.description: Using a 10mL serological pipet, transfer the remaining blood in the EMPTY 50mL tube.

source.body: Take note of the total colume of blood transfer (you need the number to calculate RPMI volume).

source.description: After completing blood transfer for neutrophil, disinfect the 15mL conical tubes with 10% bleach solution and handoff the tubes to person #2 who can move the tubes to another BSC to proceed with RBC lysis and neutrophil isolation.
After finishing the blood transfer, move serological pipet to the bleach bucket.

For each of the tubes listed in Step 5, make sure to fill with the correct buffer:
Fill 50mL conical with (2x volume of blood) RPMI at
Fill one 50mL SepMate tube with
and add through the hole in the middle of the cone inside the tube.
If the blood volume is < 3mL, use a 15mL SepMate tube and fill with
Repeat Steps 2-7 until all blood samples have been transferred to the empty 15mL falcon tube and 50mL falcon tube containing blood.
Mix all the 50mL tubes by inverting 5x.
Using a different 25mL serological pipet for each patient, transfer the diluted blood into the SepMate tube.

Slowly pipet down the side of the tube to avoid blood mixing with Ficoll that may come out of the hole in the insert (< 1 mL/s. After finishing the blood transfer, move serological pipet to bleach bucket).

Centrifuge at
with maximum acceleration and the brake on.

During centrifugation, prepare the following:
Grab Mr. Frosty from
freezer if not already in lab refrigerator
  • An ice bucket
  • Pre-fill round-bottom well 96-well plate with
  • and prepare one well per sample (for counting)
  • Label one 15mL conical for PBMC per sample, leave empty
Pre-fill round-bottom well 96-well plate with
and prepare one well per sample (for counting)
    Grab RPMI bottle from
    fridge and keep
After centrifugation, carefully remove the SepMate tube and verify the PBMC layer is visible.

source.body: If no layer is visible, centrifuge again at with the brake on.

source.description: Place the SepMate tube into a rack.

Change the centrifuge temperature to
and close the lid.

Using a 10mL serological pipet, collect
from the tube and transfer into the empty 15mL conical tube.

Place
until later.

Remove remaining plasma by aspirating and leave approximately
above the layer.
With a transfer pipet, collect and transfer PBMC layer from the SepMate tube and move to the 15mL conical tube.
Top up the conical tube to 15mL with cold RPMI.

Centrifuge
using max acceleration and max break.

Remove the supernatant by aspirating, making sure to avoid disturbing the pellet, and place tube
.

Resuspend the pellet in
.

Place
.

source.body: If pellet is not visible, resuspend in

source.description:
Add
to the roung bottom 96-well plate containing
.
Count the cells to determine the yield and number of aliquots to be frozen.

source.body: See the "Counting PBMCs" protocol.

source.description: Top up the tube to 10mL with RPMI.

Centrifuge the cell suspension at
with max acceleration and max break.

During centrifugation:
  • gather cell freezing materials: cold Crystor (CS10), refrigerated Mr. Frosty, cryo vials
  • print cryotube labels and stick on tubes: lable with "Blood PBMC", subject ID, and timepoint "PXX-DY", aliquot number, number of cells, and date
for each patient, we will freeze aliquots of
cells each and freeze the extra leftover as a spearate aliquot.

source.body: If the leftover cell is less than 200K cells, then distribute the 200K cells across all aliquots.

source.description: Remove supernatant through aspiration.
Resuspend pellet in cold Cryostor (0.5mL per 0.5M cell aliquot) using the total volume to be used to cover all aliquots accounted for per sample.
Resuspend pellet by gently pipetting up and down 10x.

source.body: The Cryostor solution is viscous so be sure to pipette up and down slowly.

source.description:
Pipet
intro cryotubes.

Transfer to Mr. Frosty and immediately place in
freezer for a maximum of
.
Record the time the blood sample was frozen.
The next day, cells can be moved from Mr. Frosty to a cardboard box (labeled PBMC-1...so on).

source.body: Note down on the spreadsheet which box and position the samples are placed.
Frozen cells can be kept between and in before being send to the Broad Institute on dry ice.

source.title: Counting PBMCs and Determining # of aliquots of PBMCs

source.description: Make sure the cell suspension is well mixed by pietting up and down.

source.title: Counting PBMCs and Determining # of aliquots of PBMCs

source.description:
Transfer
into cryovial containing
and mix with a pipet slowly, up and down 5x.

source.title: Counting PBMCs and Determining # of aliquots of PBMCs

source.description:
Load
into one of the hemocytometer reservoirs.

source.body: If using an automated cell counter(Countess- Invitrogen or BioRad), make sure to load 10ul of the diluted cells into the right plastic cell counter chamber. Insert into the machine and press the "Count Cells" button. Cells will be counted automatically and concentration per ml will be given at the end, including the viability of cells.When using the BioRad counting machine, make sure the lower gate is on 7um to avoid counting red blood cells.

source.title: Counting PBMCs and Determining # of aliquots of PBMCs

source.description:
Count the number of cells in one corner 4x4 grid (count all cells in the squares).
  • PBMC cells should have a light blue hue (due to nucleus staining)
  • count the cells in contact with the borders of only two sides of the squares

Once samples are in the freezer, centrifuge the plasma at
with max acceleration and max brake.
During centrifugation, print cryotube labels an stick on 3 cryotubes: label with "Plasma", subject ID, timepoint "PXX-DY", aliquot number, and date.

Without disturbing the pellet, aliquot
into 3 cryovials (4.5mL total).

source.body: The remaining can be discarded.

source.description:
Freeze the aliquoted plasma at
in a normal cardboard box or plastic box (labeled Plasma-1...so on).
Take note on the spreadsheet which box and position the samples are placed.
Take note of the time of when the samples were frozen.

source.body: Plasma samples can be shipped to the Broad Institute with the PBMCs.

source.description:
Before starting the upcoming sections:
  • Set centrifuge to room temperature for RBC lysis
  • Have EasySep magnet on hand
  • If the anticoagulant in the vacuatiner is not EDTA, add 1uL of 0.5M EDTA to the blood
  • Make PBS+EDTA buffer: 500mL PBS + 1mL of 0.5M EDTA and keep at room temperature
  • Label three round-bottom tubes and one 15,L conical tube with patient ID

Organize the 15mL conical tubes containing
in the hood.

source.body: This step should be performed while the other person is preparing for Ficoll isolation.

source.description:
Add
to blood using a 10Ml serological pipette and mix the sample 5 times.
When done, move the pipette to the bleach bucket.

Spin
with max acceleration and max deceleration.
Aspirate supernatant.

source.body: Be careful not to disturb the pellet.

source.description:
Resuspend cells in
at
by pipetting up and down gently 5x.
Continue to EasySep isolation.

Vortex RapidSpheres for
.

source.body: Aft anytime, DO NOT cap the 15mL tube.

Place tube into magnet.

source.body: Make sure each 15mL tube sits well at the bottm of it without lid.

source.description:
Incubate at
for
on magnet.

source.body: While on the magnet, label a second set of 15mL tubes.

source.description:
After
, using a 5mL serological pipet, transfer supernatant into new 15mL tube (tube 2).

source.body: Angle the pipet such that the tip is opporsite the magnet to avoid toughing the beads.
Procedure is negative selection so neutrophils will be in supernatant.

source.description:
Add
to the new 15mL tube (tube 2) if started with
or
if started with
Close the tube tightly and mix gentle by tilting the tube back and forth 5x (avoid bubbles.

Incubate

After

Incubate

source.body: While on magnet, label a third set of 15mL tubes.

source.description:
After
, using a 5mL serological pipet, transfer supernatant into new 15mL tube (tube 3).
Place the new tube (tube 3) with the supernatant back on th magnet.

Incubate for
at

source.body: While on magnet, label a 15mL flacon tube (tube 4).

source.description:
After
, using a 5mL serological pipet, transfer supernatant (~3.5mL) into 15mL tube (tube 4).

Spin
with full acceleration and full deceleration.
Aspirate supernatant, being careful not to disturb the pellet.

Resuspend in
and mix well.
Count the cells to determine the yield and number of aliquots to be frozen.

source.body: See "Cell Counting" in the next section.

source.description:
Add
to
.
Mix well by pipeting up and down.

Add
to a hemocytometer.

source.body: If using an automated cell counter(Countess- Invitrogen or BioRad), make sure to load 10ul of the diluted cells into the right plastic cell counter chamber. Insert into the machine and press the "Count Cells" button. Cells will be counted automatically and concentration per ml will be given at the end, including the viability of cells.When using the BioRad counting machine, make sure the lower gate is on 4um to avoid counting red blood cells.

source.description:
Count the number of cells with a hemocytometer.
  • There are four section of 4x4 grids (outlined in red below)
  • Count cells in two of the 4x4 grids (take average between the two grid counts)
  • When counting, include cells on the edges of 2 sides of each grid, and exclude cells on the edges of the other 2 sides of each grid (as shown below on right)
  • If there are not many cells, count number of cells in all four grids and take the average of all four (will be more accurate)
  • Take average of cells counted in 4x4 grids to use as "# cells" for the calculation below.

Desired outcome:
  • 2 cryotubes per patient, each tube with 100uL of neutrophil lysate in each
  • final concentration of cells in RNA lysis buffer = 1000 cells per ul
  • a total of 200K cells to split between two cryotubes
Mix 200K cells to a 1.5mL Eppendorf tube by transferring an appropriate volume of the cell suspension.
Determine fraction of cells to transfer to new tube: 20/('# cells").

Top up tube of cells to
with PBS+EDTA.

Spin
.
Make fresh RNA lysis buffer (TCL + 1% bME) according to number of samples received.

source.body: Make sure to RNAZap the surface of the hood where the lysis buffer will be used and pipettes to be used and use Rnase free tips for pipetting.

source.description: Print cryotube labels and stick on tubes: label with "Neu Lysate", subject ID and timepoint "PXX-DY", aliquot number, concentration of cells ("1k/uL"), and date.
Pipe out supernatant and remove excess with P200 (be cautious).

Resuspend in
.

source.body: If lower number of cells are received, resuspend cells in lower volumes to reach 1000 cell/1mL.

source.description:
If less than 10,000 cells are recovered, resuspend in
and note cell concentration on the cryotube. Freeze single cryotube.

After resuspending cells in
, mix well and transfer
to two cryotubes.
Place tubes on dry ice immediately.

After
, the aliquoted lysates can be moved to the
in a normal cardboard or plastic box.

source.body: Note down on the spreadsheet which box and position the samples are placed and take note of the time when the samples were frozen.

description: This protocol outlines the steps and methods for blood processing for PBMC to assist the MGH COVID-19 effort.
